section.title: Writing Mathematics, Part II
section.p: Okay, it's your turn to try writing a clear, concise proof of a statement! As we have seen, the use of English words makes proofs more approachable and understandable. Here's a small sample of commonly-used phrases in mathematical proofs. Note the use of the plural we instead of the singular I.

section.p: Moreoverand this is something that takes some practice to get used tomathematical formulas and equations, when used in English sentences, need to be treated as part of the grammar. A complete sentence is one that expresses a complete idea. For example, TJ baked brownies. is a complete sentence, while baked brownies is not. (The latter is called a phrase, or a fragment.)

section.p: Something else to note is that the two-column proof method of writing statement and reason beside each other is not a best practice. Besides the fact that it is not really used by math practitioners, these are just lists of bullet points that sometimes even obfuscate the logical links among the parts of a solution. They are sometimes useful, like for organizing your thoughts, but generally it is better form to write in complete sentences.

statement.p: Show that if a \gt b \gt 0, then a^2 \gt b^2.
Let a and b be positive real numbers with a \gt b. Then a-b and a+b are both positive. Hence their product (a-b)(a+b) = a^2 - b^2 is positive as well, implying a^2 \gt b^2.
Write a clear and complete solution to the following exercise:
Count the number of nonnegative integer solutions to the equation x_1 + x_2 + x_3 + x_4 = 35 that satisfy x_1 \geq 4, x_2 \geq 1, and x_3 \leq 5.
Try solving it yourself first before looking at the hint!
